probability_table.scenario: At least 2 lands in opening hand
probability_table.formula: P(X≥2) = 1 - [C(deck_size - lands, hand_size) + C(lands,1)*C(deck_size - lands, hand_size - 1)] / C(deck_size, hand_size)
probability_table.explanation: Calculate the chance of drawing two or more lands (successes) from a 99‑card deck using the hypergeometric distribution.

probability_table.scenario: At least 1 ramp spell by turn 3
probability_table.formula: P(X≥1) = 1 - C(deck_size - ramp_spells, draws)/C(deck_size, draws) where draws = 10
probability_table.explanation: The probability of having at least one of the twelve ramp spells in the first ten cards (7 in hand + three draws)

good_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Forest, Sol Ring, Llanowar Elves, Cultivate, Selvala, Beast Whisperer
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands plus two pieces of early ramp (Sol Ring and Llanowar Elves) let you accelerate into bigger spells; Cultivate fixes colours and Selvala/Beast Whisperer provide card draw.

good_keep_examples.hand: Nykthos, Shrine to Nyx, Forest, Arcane Signet, Nature's Lore, Oracle of Mul Daya, Avenger of Zendikar
good_keep_examples.reason: The land plus two ramp spells (Signet and Nature's Lore) ensure turn‑three Oracle; Avenger is a payoff once you’ve ramped.

good_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Castle Garenbrig, Elvish Mystic, Three Visits, Beast Within, Tooth and Nail, Woodfall Primus
good_keep_examples.reason: With two lands and cheap ramp (Mystic/Three Visits) you can cast removal or set up Tooth and Nail quickly.

good_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Forest, Fyndhorn Elves, Mana Crypt, Harmonize, Craterhoof Behemoth, Reclamation Sage
good_keep_examples.reason: Mana Crypt plus Fyndhorn Elves accelerate you to Harmonize while giving a removal option (Reclamation Sage); Craterhoof is a finisher.

good_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Spire Garden, Arcane Signet, Solemn Simulacrum, Finale of Devastation, Llanowar Visionary, Worldly Tutor

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Sol Ring, Craterhoof Behemoth, Tooth and Nail, Genesis Wave, Avenger of Zendikar, Vorinclex
bad_keep_examples.reason: Despite Sol Ring, a one‑land hand with nothing to do until six mana will often stall.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Nykthos, Gaea's Cradle, Kozilek, Ulamog, Avenger of Zendikar, Finale of Devastation, Beastmaster Ascension, Eternal Witness
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only one land and several double‑digit mana spells make this unkeepable.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Forest, Forest, Beast Within, Krosan Grip, Reclamation Sage, Naturalize

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Yavimaya Coast, Eternal Witness, Primal Command, Seasons Past, Concordant Crossroads, Traverse the Outlands
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands but no early ramp; spells start at four or five mana and you risk falling behind.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Forest, Fabled Passage, Carpet of Flowers, Triumph of the Hordes, Finale of Devastation, Soul's Majesty
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands but only pump spells and no creatures; Carpet of Flowers rarely ramps in mono‑green, making the hand slow.

Mono-Green Ramp.guidelines: In mono‑green Commander decks you generally want at least two lands and one or two ramp pieces. A hand with only one land is risky unless you also have Sol Ring plus a cheap mana dork. Avoid hands full of huge creatures without ways to cast them; prioritize early ramp and card draw.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Sol Ring, Lightning Bolt, Torbran, Chandra, Faithless Looting
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands plus Sol Ring supply plenty of mana; Faithless Looting digs and Torbran amplifies your burn.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Castle Embereth, Arcane Signet, Goblin Arsonist, Reckless Fireweaver, Torbran, Impact Tremors
good_keep_examples.reason: Mana rocks and cheap creatures advance your aggressive plan; Torbran and Impact Tremors turn small creatures into big damage.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Fire Diamond, Dockside Extortionist, Lightning Bolt, Chaos Warp, Chandra, Torch of Defiance
good_keep_examples.reason: Fire Diamond and Dockside ramp into Chandra; Lightning Bolt and Chaos Warp provide early interaction.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Mind Stone, Skullclamp, Chainer's Torch, Outpost Siege, Purphoros, God of the Forge
good_keep_examples.reason: Mind Stone ramps, Skullclamp draws cards and Purphoros plus Siege provide game‑long value.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Great Furnace, Sol Ring, Ragavan, Nimble Pilferer, Abrade, Torbran, Shattering Spree
good_keep_examples.reason: Sol Ring plus Ragavan accelerate your mana; removal keeps opponents off balance.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Torbran, Blasphemous Act, Vandalblast, Insurrection, Mana Geyser, Chandra's Ignition
bad_keep_examples.reason: One land and a handful of expensive spells means you won’t cast anything until turn four or five.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Great Furnace, Forgotten Cave, Ghirapur Aether Grid, Embercleave, Chaos Warp, Outpost Siege, Flames of the Firebrand
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands but no early creatures or ramp; the curve starts at three mana.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Mountain, Mountain, Lightning Bolt, Shock, Skullcrack

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Surveyor's Scope, Wayfarer's Bauble, Burnished Hart, Solemn Simulacrum, Myr Battlesphere

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Cavern of Souls, Impact Tremors, Warstorm Surge, Terror of the Peaks, Insurrection, Blasphemous Act
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands but spells cost five or more; the hand lacks cheap interaction or ramp.

Mono-Red Aggro.guidelines: Aggro in Commander still needs at least two lands and a mana rock. Look for cheap creatures or burn spells to start pressuring opponents. Avoid one‑land hands unless you have both Sol Ring and a cheap creature. Large sweeper‑only hands are slow; keep a mix of interaction and threats.

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Mountain, Izzet Signet, Ponder, Arcane Denial, Guttersnipe, Talrand, Sky Summoner
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands plus a signet guarantee mana; cheap cantrips and counters set up your token generators.

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Steam Vents, Sol Ring, Brainstorm, Lightning Bolt, Young Pyromancer, Thousand‑Year Storm

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Island, Arcane Signet, Preordain, Counterspell, Niv‑Mizzet, Parun, Mana Drain

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Electrodominance, Comet Storm, Crackle with Power, Mizzix's Mastery, Past in Flames, Expansion/Explosion

Izzet Spellslinger.guidelines: Izzet spellslinger wants at least two lands (ideally a red and a blue source) plus a mana rock or cheap cantrip. A single‑land hand is usually a mulligan unless you have Sol Ring and Brainstorm. Avoid hands full of five‑plus‑mana payoffs without the ramp to cast them; prioritize fixing and card selection.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Forest, Arcane Signet, Llanowar Elves, Chatterfang, the Squirrel General, Blood Artist, Viscera Seer
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and two ramp pieces let you curve into your commander; Blood Artist and Viscera Seer support the sacrifice plan.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Bloom Tender, Golgari Signet, Reanimate, Skullclamp, Chainer's Edict, Chatterfang

good_keep_examples.reason: Early ramp and card advantage (Loam); Yawgmoth and Skeleton form a repeatable draw engine.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Zulaport Cutthroat, Poison‑Tip Archer, Blood Artist, Dictate of Erebos, Grave Pact

Golgari Aristocrats.guidelines: Aristocrats decks need a mix of lands, ramp and cheap creatures to sacrifice. Aim for two lands plus a mana rock or mana dork and at least one creature and one payoff (e.g., Blood Artist). Hands full of expensive reanimation targets without enablers should be mulliganed.

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Plains, Arcane Signet, Swords to Plowshares, Ponder, Brago, King Eternal, Flicker of Fate
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and a signet ensure mana; removal and cantrips set up Brago and flicker synergy.

good_keep_examples.reason: Mana fixing plus cheap interaction and card draw; Ghostly Flicker and Mulldrifter provide value.

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Flooded Strand, Sol Ring, Counterspell, Wall of Omens, Teferi, Time Raveler, Cloudblazer

good_keep_examples.hand: Plains, Seachrome Coast, Mind Stone, Supreme Verdict, Propaganda, Azorius Signet, Brago, King Eternal
good_keep_examples.reason: Double ramp (Mind Stone and Signet) gets you to board wipes and Propaganda quickly.

good_keep_examples.hand: Island, Plains, Command Tower, Azorius Signet, Smothering Tithe, Cyclonic Rift, Sakashima's Student

bad_keep_examples.hand: Plains, Plains, Plains, Supreme Verdict, Sphinx's Revelation, Approach of the Second Sun, Terminus

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Arcane Laboratory, Stasis, Blind Obedience, Propaganda, Sphere of Safety, Swords to Plowshares

bad_keep_examples.hand: Plains, Plains, Plains, Plains, Mana Drain, Counterspell, Force of Will

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Plains, Ghostly Flicker, Ephemerate, Momentary Blink, Ghostway, Archaeomancer
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands but all flicker spells with no creatures to flicker; you will spin your wheels.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Island, Island, Mana Crypt, Sol Ring, Lotus Petal, Sensei's Divining Top
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three blue sources and plenty of artifacts but almost no white; you risk colour screw and have no spells.

Azorius Control.guidelines: Azorius control values two or three lands (including both colours), a mana rock and early interaction. Don’t keep hands with only one coloured source or with a clump of four‑plus‑mana spells. Include at least one card draw or flicker engine to sustain resources.

good_keep_examples.reason: Two five‑colour lands and two ramp spells (Signet and Farseek) fix your mana; Chromatic Lantern and Jodah enable five‑colour payoffs.

good_keep_examples.hand: City of Brass, Mana Confluence, Birds of Paradise, Nature's Lore, Cultivate, Teferi, Time Raveler, Niv‑Mizzet Reborn
good_keep_examples.reason: Two rainbow lands and cheap ramp ensure you can cast multi‑colour threats; Niv‑Mizzet is a payoff.

good_keep_examples.hand: Savannah, Tropical Island, Sol Ring, Kodama's Reach, Knight of the Reliquary, Growth Spiral, Omnath, Locus of Creation
good_keep_examples.reason: Dual lands plus Sol Ring and Kodama's Reach guarantee colour fixing; Growth Spiral and Omnath provide card advantage.

good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands that produce any colour plus two ramp spells give you a fast start; Maelstrom Wanderer and Jodah are finishers.

good_keep_examples.hand: Exotic Orchard, Spire of Industry, Chromatic Lantern, Mirari's Wake, Worldly Tutor, Swords to Plowshares, Teferi's Protection
good_keep_examples.reason: Chromatic Lantern and Exotic Orchard fix your colours; Mirari's Wake doubles your mana; Tutor and Protection provide answers.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Plains, Plains, Plains, Swamp, Mountain, Forest, Yawgmoth's Will
bad_keep_examples.reason: Seven basics with no blue means you can't cast many of your five‑colour spells; there's no ramp or card draw.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Command Tower, Lotus Field, Niv‑Mizzet, Parun, Maelstrom Wanderer, Tivit, Seller of Secrets, Zacama, Primal Calamity, Omnath, Locus of All
bad_keep_examples.reason: One land and a handful of seven‑plus‑mana spells; you will be unable to cast anything.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Reflecting Pool, Exotic Orchard, Mana Confluence, Mana Confluence, Fist of Suns, Jodah, Archmage Eternal, Door to Nothingness, Maelstrom Nexus
bad_keep_examples.reason: Four lands but no ramp; your spells cost five or more and require set‑up.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Mountain, Forest, Blood Crypt, Stomping Ground, Steam Vents, Overgrown Tomb

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Mana Confluence, Lightning Bolt, Swords to Plowshares, Path to Exile, Abrupt Decay, Assassin's Trophy
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and a handful of removal spells but no ramp or threats; you'll answer threats but never progress your own game.

5-Color Goodstuff.guidelines: Five‑colour decks must prioritise colour fixing; keep hands with two sources that produce any colour plus ramp like Farseek or Signets. Avoid hands with a single land or only basic lands. Because your spells are expensive, you need early ramp and fixing to ensure you can cast them.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Goblin Guide, Monastery Swiftspear, Lightning Bolt, Lava Spike, Rift Bolt
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and multiple one‑mana spells let you apply pressure immediately.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Bloodstained Mire, Lava Dart, Lightning Helix, Boros Charm, Skewer the Critics, Eidolon of the Great Revel
good_keep_examples.reason: You have two lands, removal/burn and a two‑mana threat; the fetch land fixes white for Helix and Boros Charm.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Monastery Swiftspear, Lava Spike, Searing Blaze, Skullcrack, Fireblast
good_keep_examples.reason: You can cast two one‑mana burn spells on turn one and two; Fireblast is a finisher.

good_keep_examples.hand: Arid Mesa, Sacred Foundry, Lightning Bolt, Lava Spike, Light Up the Stage, Roiling Vortex, Rift Bolt
good_keep_examples.reason: Fetch into Shockland provides white mana; Light Up the Stage refuels your hand.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Inspiring Vantage, Eidolon of the Great Revel, Lava Spike, Lightning Strike, Deflecting Palm, Searing Blaze
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands support two‑drop Eidolon and several burn spells; Deflecting Palm punishes big attackers.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Mountain, Lightning Bolt, Flame Rift, Boros Charm, Atarka's Command
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands and mostly two‑mana spells slow your start; you risk flooding.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Lightning Helix, Lightning Helix, Boros Charm, Skullcrack, Skullcrack, Fireblast
bad_keep_examples.reason: One land with two‑mana spells requires drawing a second land quickly; a risky keep.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Mountain, Mountain, Lava Spike, Shard Volley, Roiling Vortex, Sunbaked Canyon
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands and only one real threat; you'll flood out before killing your opponent.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Sunbaked Canyon, Inspiring Vantage, Inspiring Vantage, Lightning Helix, Searing Blaze, Shard Volley

Modern Burn.guidelines: Modern Burn tends to keep hands with two to three lands and at least three spells that cost one or two mana. One‑land hands can be kept only if they contain multiple one‑drop spells and your spells cost one; hands with three or more lands or with sideboard cards belong in the mulligan pile.

good_keep_examples.reason: Mind Stone and Sphere fix your colours; Ugin's Labyrinth provides additional mana; Karn and Oblivion Stone handle threats.

good_keep_examples.hand: Urza's Power Plant, Urza's Mine, Sanctum of Ugin, Expedition Map, Sylvan Scrying, Chromatic Sphere, Ugin, the Spirit Dragon

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Swamp, Wastes, Oblivion Stone, Oblivion Stone, Wurmcoil Engine, Ugin, the Spirit Dragon

bad_keep_examples.hand: Forest, Forest, Forest, Forest, Mind Stone, Expedition Map, Chromatic Star
bad_keep_examples.reason: Four forests mean you’re far from Tron and have no payoffs; you'll lose to other fast decks.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Urza's Mine, Urza's Mine, Urza's Mine, Chromatic Sphere, Chromatic Star, Expedition Map, Walking Ballista
bad_keep_examples.reason: Triple of the same Tron land makes it nearly impossible to assemble Tron quickly; walking Ballista alone cannot win.

Modern Tron.guidelines: Tron hands need at least two different Urza lands or a tutor (Expedition Map, Sylvan Scrying) plus a payoff. Mulligan hands with only one Tron piece or multiple copies of the same one. Keep a mix of lands, fixing, and a high‑impact threat.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Mutavault, Thoughtseize, Gifted Aetherborn, Graveyard Trespasser, Fatal Push, Castle Locthwain
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands (one being Mutavault) enable early discard and removal; Aetherborn and Trespasser put pressure.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Forsaken Miner, Knight of the Ebon Legion, Murderous Rider, Liliana of the Veil, Duress
good_keep_examples.reason: Two swamps support your early one‑drops and removal; Liliana provides mid‑game value.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Thoughtseize, Go for the Throat, Graveyard Trespasser, Blade of the Oni, Castle Locthwain
good_keep_examples.reason: Discard, removal and a threat make for a balanced opener.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Gifted Aetherborn, Fatal Push, Graveyard Trespasser, Invoke Despair, Field of Ruin
good_keep_examples.reason: Early removal and lifelink to stabilise; Invoke Despair provides reach.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Castle Locthwain, Mutavault, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Graveyard Trespasser, Duress, Fatal Push
good_keep_examples.reason: Three lands including a utility land support early interaction and Inti sets up aggressive draws.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mutavault, Field of Ruin, Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth, Invoke Despair, Invoke Despair, Liliana of the Veil, Sheoldred, the Apocalypse
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only colourless lands and expensive spells; you cannot cast anything before turn four.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Swamp, Swamp, Duress, Go for the Throat, Fatal Push
bad_keep_examples.reason: Four lands and only disruption; you risk drawing too many lands and not enough threats.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Thoughtseize, Thoughtseize, Duress, Go for the Throat, Fatal Push, Liliana of the Veil
bad_keep_examples.reason: One land with four discard/removal spells requires drawing multiple lands; a risky keep.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mutavault, Castle Locthwain, Mutavault, Swamp, Sheoldred, the Apocalypse, Invoke Despair, Blade of the Oni
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only one black source among four lands; double‑black spells will be hard to cast.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Field of Ruin, Field of Ruin, Graveyard Trespasser, Graveyard Trespasser, Graveyard Trespasser, Graveyard Trespasser
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only one black source and four copies of the same three‑drop; you need diversity and mana fixing.

Pioneer Mono-Black Aggro.guidelines: Pioneer mono‑black wants two to three black sources and at least one early creature or discard spell. Avoid hands with colourless lands and no swamps. One‑land hands with multiple discard spells are risky; prioritize hands that curve out from one to three mana.

good_keep_examples.hand: Volcanic Island, Wasteland, Delver of Secrets, Brainstorm, Lightning Bolt, Daze, Ponder
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands with access to both colours, a cheap threat, a cantrip, a removal spell and a free counterspell.

good_keep_examples.hand: Flooded Strand, Volcanic Island, Dragon's Rage Channeler, Expressive Iteration, Force of Will, Murktide Regent, Lightning Bolt
good_keep_examples.reason: Fetchland plus Volcanic ensures both colours; Channeler and Iteration build card advantage and Force/Murktide provide power.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mystic Sanctuary, Island, Delver of Secrets, Brainstorm, Spell Pierce, Lightning Bolt, Mishra's Bauble
good_keep_examples.reason: The sanctuary plus Island yield blue mana; you have a threat, a removal spell and a cantrip.

good_keep_examples.hand: Wasteland, Volcanic Island, Ragavan, Nimble Pilferer, Ponder, Force of Will, Lightning Bolt
good_keep_examples.reason: You can deploy Ragavan and disrupt with Force; Wasteland pressures opponent’s mana.

good_keep_examples.hand: Arid Mesa, Scalding Tarn, Delver of Secrets, Brainstorm, Murktide Regent, Daze, Expressive Iteration
good_keep_examples.reason: Fetchlands find your duals; Delver and Daze apply early pressure; Iteration and Murktide provide late‑game strength.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Mystic Sanctuary, Wasteland, Wasteland, Murktide Regent, Murktide Regent, Daze, Force of Will
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only one source of coloured mana (Mystic Sanctuary) and too many five‑mana threats.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Island, Island, Island, Brainstorm, Ponder, Ponder, Expressive Iteration
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands and all cantrips but no threats or interaction; you risk drawing more lands and falling behind.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Volcanic Island, Wasteland, Daze, Force of Will, Spell Pierce, Lightning Bolt, Consider
bad_keep_examples.reason: No creature to pressure the opponent; all interaction and no clock.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Volcanic Island, Volcanic Island, Chain Lightning, Lightning Bolt, Lightning Bolt, Lightning Bolt, Pyroblast
bad_keep_examples.reason: Too many burn spells and no blue source; you may not cast Pyroblast and have no cantrips.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Volcanic Island, Arid Mesa, Flooded Strand, Ponder, Preordain, Brainstorm, Consider
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands and only cantrips; you may spin your wheels without a threat or disruption.

Legacy Delver.guidelines: Delver decks aim for two lands (ideally a fetchland + dual), a cheap threat (Delver/Ragavan), and a cantrip or counterspell. One‑land hands are keepable only with cantrip plus free countermagic. Avoid hands full of spells but no threats or hands with too many expensive cards.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Mountain, Bloodletter of Aclazotz, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Bitter Triumph, The End, Suplex
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and both colours; you have an early threat, removal and a mid‑game payoff.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Blazemire Verge, Fear of Missing Out, Cecil, Dark Knight, Bitter Triumph, Fire Magic, Suplex
good_keep_examples.reason: Mana fixing plus a mix of removal and creatures; Cecil and Fire Magic provide value.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Blazemire Verge, Qarsi Revenant, The End, Fire Magic, Blackcleave Cliffs, Summon: Brynhildr
good_keep_examples.reason: Three lands (one in spell form) ensure you hit your curve; removal and a strong creature make for a solid hand.

good_keep_examples.hand: Mountain, Blazemire Verge, Bitter Triumph, The End, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Fire Magic, Suplex
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands plus Inti and removal allow you to develop on curve.

good_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Bloodletter of Aclazotz, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Bitter Triumph, Fire Magic, Fear of Missing Out
good_keep_examples.reason: Two lands and two early threats; removal and card advantage spells help control the mid‑game.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Cecil, Dark Knight, Fear of Missing Out, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Qarsi Revenant, Fire Magic, Suplex
bad_keep_examples.reason: Only one land and several three‑drops make the hand too slow.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Swamp, Swamp, Bitter Triumph, The End, Fear of Missing Out, Fear of Missing Out
bad_keep_examples.reason: Four lands and only removal/draw spells; you may flood and never apply pressure.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Blazemire Verge, Sulfurous Springs, Soulstone Sanctuary, Cecil, Dark Knight, Fear of Missing Out, Fire Magic, Bitter Triumph
bad_keep_examples.reason: Two lands but most spells cost three or more; Soulstone Sanctuary is not helpful early.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Mountain, Blazemire Verge, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Inti, Seneschal of the Sun, Bloodletter of Aclazotz, Fear of Missing Out
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands but multiple copies of Inti and no removal; you may get stuck if Inti dies.

bad_keep_examples.hand: Swamp, Swamp, Swamp, Suplex, Suplex, Fire Magic, Fire Magic, Fear of Missing Out
bad_keep_examples.reason: Three lands and many expensive spells; you lack early plays.

Standard Midrange.guidelines: Midrange decks want two to three lands and a mix of cheap removal and creatures. Hands with only one land should be mulled unless you have card draw to find more; hands with four lands risk flooding. Ensure you have both colours if playing two‑colour decks and at least one removal spell or threat.

consistency_metrics.definition: Number of cards providing similar effects or roles (ramp, burn, cantrips, sacrifice outlets, etc.). High redundancy improves consistency because you are more likely to draw the function you need.
Percentage of the deck devoted to the deck’s main game plan or theme. Calculated as (number of theme cards) ÷ (deck size). Higher densities mean your deck is more focused.

Number of threat cards (creatures, win conditions or burn spells) divided by the number of answer cards (removal, counterspells). A higher ratio implies a more aggressive plan while a lower ratio indicates a control strategy.
